titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the John Sung Papers
titlestmt.author: Martha Lund Smalley and Li Tang

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 26, 2019 at 22:15

did.abstract: John Sung (1901-1944) was a prominent Chinese Christian evangelist. This collection consists of of a complete collection of his diaries spanning from 1919 to 1944, correspondence and postcards (primarily to his parents), and his writings and notes (such as sermons, Bible stories, reflections on his illness, prayer lists, etc.)

list.item: I. Compilation of Correspondence and Writings, 1919-1927

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: John Sung (宋尚節 Song Shangjie, or Siong Ceh Sung in his preferred Anglicization) was born on September 27, 1901 in Xinghua 興化 (now Putian 莆田), Fujian 福建 Province, the son of a Methodist pastor. He grew up in the church and established connections with American missionaries who facilitated his travel to the United States in 1920 to continue his education. Despite working various jobs to support himself, Sung was able to complete a Bachelor's degree in three years at Ohio Wesleyan University and went on to complete a Master's degree (1924) and Ph.D. (1926) in Chemistry at Ohio State University, all with academic distinction.

Sung originally had come to the United States with the intent to study Bible and theology but he was drawn to science. After completing his Ph.D. in Chemistry, however, Sung returned to his religious commitment and entered Union Theological Seminary in New York. Sung had a dramatic conversion experience on February 10, 1927 after attending evangelistic meetings in New York. This "born-again" experience caused Sung to reject the more liberal theology of many of his professors at Union Seminary and his behavior over the next several days was outspoken and erratic. Leaders at Union Seminary determined that Sung had become mentally unstable and eventually he was voluntarily admitted to Bloomingdale Hospital, a psychiatric facility in White Plains, New York. While in the hospital for 193 days, Sung read through the Bible many times and made extensive notes.

An American clergyman facilitated Sung's release from the hospital and he returned to China in October 1927. After teaching chemistry and Bible at a Methodist high school in Fujian for one year, Sung resigned and joined an evangelistic band. He was engaged in preaching and teaching in rural churches for three years under the auspices of the Methodist Bishop of the region. From 1930 to 1933 he served under the Bethel Evangelistic Band, but after disagreements with its leadership he left to become an independent itinerant revivalist and evangelist. Known as a faith healer, Sung attracted huge crowds as he evangelized throughout China and on five journeys to Southeast Asia.

For more than eight years, Sung traveled widely, preaching and teaching, enduring strenuous travel and long periods of separation from his family. He reputedly converted as many as 100,000 people and was known as a faith healer. Sung's own health was compromised by painful anal fistulas or hemorrhoids, which eventually caused his death on August 18, 1944 at the age of 42.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: John Sung's reputation has long been based primarily on his published autobiography and excerpts from his diaries that were selected and published by his daughter. The original correspondence, writings, and extensive diaries of Sung in this collection provide the basis for re-analysis of his life and work.

The documents in Series I, Compilation of Correspondence and Writings, were contained in a hand-stitched bound volume of paper sheets. Postcards and letters to Sung's parents and other documents were glued into the volume or enclosed in it. There are also writings on the sheets of the volume itself. The volume has been disbound for preservation and access purposes,with the sheets and enclosures placed in a series of folders, in their original order.
Series II, Correspondence, contains a small amount of postcards and letters written by Sung to his parents.

The Diaries of Series III include more than fifty hand-bound volumes of closely written journals. Sung's diaries, which make up the bulk of John Sung papers, are enormously valuable for developing a comprehensive and unbiased understanding of Sung. The diaries begin June 30 of 1919, after Sung graduated from the Zheli Secondary School 哲理中學in Fujian, and they end on May 1st of 1944, three and a half months before he passed away.

The miscellaneous, random, and detailed-oriented nature of Sung's diaries may reflect the biji 筆記 or miscellaneous notes genre of Chinese classical literature. He chronicled his numerous ministry trips in China and Southeast Asia and listed all people who were converted, particularly in the later diaries. Sung also recorded his daily schedule, dreams, health issues, personal and family events, and described his observations and opinions of Chinese compatriots, society, culture and politics.
Digital copies of the diaries from 1927 November to 1944 are available at the repository for use by qualified researchers. Consult with the Special Collections Librarian regarding use.
Series IV, Writings and Notes, includes handwritten sermons, lists of individuals for whom Sung prayed, and Sung's reflections on his illness.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The material is open for research.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Digital copies for some items are available at the repository, restricted to use by qualified academic researchers.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: John Sung Papers (RG 263), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library

controlaccess.subject: Evangelistic work -- China -- History -- 20th Century
Evangelistic work -- Southeast Asia -- History -- 20th Century

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The documents in this series were contained in a hand-stitched bound volume of paper sheets. Postcards and letters to Sung's parents and other documents were glued into the volume or enclosed in it. There are also writings on the sheets of the volume itself. The volume has been disbound for preservation and access purposes, with the sheets and enclosures placed in a series of folders, in their original order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sung's early diaries are dated using the Chinese lunar calendar. These diary entries are dated the 3rd day of the 6th month to the 20th day of the 6th month.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Diaries entries, dated by the Chinese lunar calendar as 6/21 - 7/23

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sheets include diary entries and correspondence. Diary entries are dated 7/25 - 12/15 by Chinese lunar calendar.

did.unittitle: Four postcards from Sung to his parents in Fujiann, written from Ohio and Niagara Falls
Sung's letter to his parents regarding his decision to pursue a Ph.D. in Chemistry at Ohio State University

did.unittitle: English-language diary from period in Bloomingdale Hospital
English-language diary from period in Bloomingdale Hospital, with drawings, diagrams, magazine clipping
English and Chinese-language entries from period in Bloomingdale Hospital (loose sheets)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The entries dated October 15 to November 4 describe Sung's journey back to China.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bound volumes are all in Chinese language. They consist of sheets of paper with a stitched binding and covers constructed from sheets taken from magazines or from plain paper. A special sign marks the beginning of a new entry in the diaries.
